content: The Act may be cited as the "Register of Copyrights Selection and Accountability Act of 2017". It pertains to the selection and accountability of the Register of Copyrights. The "Register of Copyrights Selection and Accountability Act of 2017" amends Section 701 of title 17, United States Code, regarding the appointment and qualifications of the Register of Copyrights. The Register must be a U.S. citizen with expertise in copyright law and capable of overseeing information technology systems. The appointment is made by the President. The "Register of Copyrights Selection and Accountability Act of 2017" amends Section 701 of title 17, United States Code, regarding the appointment and qualifications of the Register of Copyrights. The Register must be a U.S. citizen with expertise in copyright law and capable of overseeing information technology systems. The appointment is made by the President with the advice and consent of the Senate. The Act also specifies the duties and oath of the Register of Copyrights. The Register of Copyrights must take an oath before assuming office and can be removed by the President, with notification to Congress. They serve a 10-year term and can continue until a successor is appointed. The Register of Copyrights serves a 10-year term and may continue until a successor is appointed. A panel recommends individuals for the position to the President, including the Speaker of the House of Representatives. The Register may be reappointed with Senate advice and consent. The Register of Copyrights serves a 10-year term and may continue until a successor is appointed. A panel recommends individuals for the position to the President, including key officials like the Speaker of the House of Representatives. The process involves Senate advice and consent for reappointment. The subsections of the appointment process have been redesigned and updated with specific requirements. The amendments made by subsection (a) regarding the appointment of the Register of Copyrights apply to vacancies after January 1, 2017. If a Register is appointed between January 1, 2017, and the enactment of this Act, they must meet the new requirements or be replaced. SEC. 3. CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not affect the mandatory deposit requirements in title 17, United States Code.
